title: About
text:
I am currently a Ph.D. candidate in Geophysics at the University of Alberta (UofA). I conduct research under the guidance of Prof. Mauricio Sacchi that focuses on developing deep-learning tools for solving inverse problems in seismic imaging and signal processing.
Before coming to the UofA 🇨🇦 , I received a B.S. (2015) in geophysical engineering from Simon Bolivar University 🇻🇪 and an M.S. (2019) in computational geophysics from the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro 🇧🇷.
My current research topics include:

title: Research
text:
Deep-learning-based least-squares migration
Leveraging learned iterative reconstruction for LSRTM of synthetic and real seismic data. 


Seismic inversion with nullspace networks
Deep neural networks explore the null space of the forward operator, enabling data-consistent and uncertainty-aware high resolution reconstruction of post-stack data.



Reflection waveform inversion
Spetial flavor of FWI that exploits the tenuous low-wavenumber 🐰 reflection kernel to recover a macro velicity model from reflection data.



 





Imaging with Right and left deep-learning preconditioniners
Accelerating seismimc imaging through deep neural networks trained from migrated and re-migrated data/models to avoid dependance on unavailable ground-truth labels while roughly approximate the inverse Hessian and data resolution matrices.  


Extended-domain LSRTM
I developed a Python/Fortran package focused on extended-domain (e.g., subsurface-offset, angle, time-shift, shot and receiver) imaing and inversion.
 


Plane-wave FD
Examples with acoustic and elastic media. Imaging/plane wave CIGs coming soon! 


Reducing RTM artefacts via \(f-k\) domain wavefield decomposition
A simple implementation of frequency-wavenumber filtering to get rid of strong backscattering noise present in RTM sections.



Master’s thesis (in Portuguese)
Least-squares migration and full-waveform inversion in the time domain via adjoint-state methods.
